newsitem.title: HONG KONG: New HK issues offer excitement in slow market.
newsitem.headline: New HK issues offer excitement in slow market.

text.p: While Hong Kong's blue-chip stocks pursue an expected consolidation, investors are likely to find initial public offerings (IPO) a more exciting alternative in coming weeks, analysts said.
Since reaching an all-time high of 14,004.93 on January 16, the Hang Seng blue-chip index has shed 560 points, closing at 13,444.85 on Friday.
Meanwhile, new listings have put on a strong performance and offered quick profits, analysts said.

"If we can easily make money from buying blue chips, no one will look into IPOs. And as the market is quiet, more people will look at IPOs," said Percy Au-young, director of research at DBS Securities.
"Many new listings have performed very well and most of them have traded above their issue price. They were spectacular after their listings," he added.
Investors have been reducing heavily overweight positions in Hong Kong over recent weeks, which has contributed to the market's decline, brokers said.

"Many fund managers are still overweighted Hong Kong," said Eugene Law, director at Lippo Securities Ltd. "They will pay attention to IPOs to fill up the gap in a quiet market and for short-term investments."

Rumours concerning the health of China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping also had contributed to a slide in share prices though his death last Wednesday removed the uncertainty that had been hurting the market, analysts said.
"The market is healthier after the recent correction and the removal of the element of uncertainty," said Law.
"Overall investment sentiment has improved. The IPO market, the highly visible part of the market, is likely to attract many investors' attention."

Analysts said there was a good mix of offerings in the pipeline. The 250 million share IPO of Shum Yip Investment Ltd, a company backed by the Shenzhen municipal government, was considered the most attractive.
Shum Yip's main business is property investment and development but it has diversified into transportation.
The subscription period for the offering, priced at HK$1.85 per share, opened last Friday and will run until February 26.
Dealing in the stock is due to begin on March 7.

"I would regard Shum Yip as a mini red-chip play or mini conglomerate, and possible future asset injections will likely boost the IPO response," said Tony Yung, research manager at Tai Fook Securities.
Capacitors and resistors-maker Man Yue International Holdings Ltd is offering 55 million new shares at HK$1.08 each.
The subscription period for its IPO closed last Friday and trading in the shares is to begin on March 5.
"The response to the two IPOs will give an indication to the market of the impact of recent fluctuations," said Patrick Cheng, corporate finance director at HSBC Investment Banking.

Boto Co Ltd, which makes artificial Christmas trees, said last week it would issue 125.4 million new shares at HK$1.28 each. The IPO is due to run from February 24-27, with dealing in the shares due to begin on March 10.
Tai Shan Properties Ltd, a spinoff of Great Eagle Holdings Ltd, is expected to issue 225 million new shares at HK$10.60 to HK$11.45 per share, market sources said.
Its IPO is expected to run from March 4-7, with dealing in the shares expected to begin on March 14, they added.
Market sources also said leather garments maker Peking Apparel International Group Ltd was due to list in March.
